necessary to add that, since from the saddle one may go down
in two diﬀerent directions (i.e., one may freely select the + or
sign for the perturbation), two distinct minima can be
generated. However, the two optimized structures, which at
ﬁrst sight appeared to display opposite rotations of the phenyls,
are actually identical but for a shift of the origin. Thus, the
saddle structure may be described as an average of two

Besides the energy considerations, a relevant diﬀerence
between the H-bonding networks of the two phases could be
has only two, but double H-bonded, with one
H-bonding site at the oxygen even unmatched. While the
variation in the energetics is hardly justifying any diﬀerences in
the dissolution behavior, the steric arrangement of H-bonding
might be the cause of its
The evaluation of the structure within a thin ﬁlm is challenging
due to diﬀerent reasons. By using a combination of CSP
calculations with GIXD experiments and some help from
Raman spectroscopy, the structure of phenytoin in its thin ﬁlm
) could be solved. The results suggest that the
diﬀerence in the steric H-bonding network is likely the reason
for the faster dissolution of the surface induced thin ﬁlm form
, which is the bulk form. In
general, the structure solving procedure employed here, with
the assistance of CSP methods, allows for the use of limited
experimental data to gain access to the packing arrangement of
organic molecules. It can be expected that this may represent
an optimal approach when dealing not only with GIXD data
from thin ﬁlms but could be extended to single crystal X-ray
diﬀraction of poor data, neutron diﬀraction, or even electron
diﬀraction, minimizing the requirement of high quality crystal
